Her group is located in Santiago, the second biggest city in the Dominican Republic, and an area famous for its tobacco and beef production. This area, like nearly all impoverished areas of the Dominican Republic, suffers from unreliable electricity and running water (none of which is potable).

loans.use: To buy more cosmetics and household products to sell

loans.name: Nicanora

texts.en:
Nicanora A. is a married woman who lives in Prk. Masinadyahon, Brgy. Binicuil, Kabankalan City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating three business ventures:  pig fattening, a general store and an eatery businesses.  Her husband, Cezar A., is 73 years old.  They have eight children who are 32 to 50 years old. 

Nicanora joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1989 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 17 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Nicanora has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 29,500 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 12,000, thus, uplifting the family's standard of living.  

This time, for her 18th loan, she is borrowing PHP 29,500, which she intends to use as additional working capital so that she can continue to save up for the future of her family.  Nicanora A. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the  NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Clementina

texts.en:
Clementina S. is from the village of Panduma, Tukuran, Zamboanga Del Sur. She is 45 years-old and married with six school-aged children. To make a living, Clementina owns and operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income comes from buying and selling dried fish and vegetables in the local community. Clementina has been engaged in her business for over ten years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Clementina joined Kiva partner GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Clementina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell.  Clementina is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the fifth loan taken out by Clementina from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve the general living conditions of the her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fishers and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business.

loans.name: Dios Es Mi Pastor Group

texts.en:
Valerus is the coordinator of her group, Dios es mi Pastor 3 (God is my Pastor). She makes her home in a simple structure with her long term partner and 2 children. She says that her most difficult challenges are buying land and building her house. In the meantime, she plans to continue enjoying to cook.

Valerus is excited to be taking her 3rd loan with Esperanza after having successfully repaid her previous loan and grown her business. She has had her business for 10 years. She started with a loan. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business by buying items such as rice, oil, seasoning, meats and vegetables. She cooks and sells food to construction workers and others. She will use the profits to help with housing payments and her children's schooling. It is like an investment. 

This Esperanza associate began with us because, with the loan, she can buy more merchandise and improve her business. Her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican (many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti) clients generally. Her group is located in San Pedro de Macoris, a city famous for baseball players and sugar cane industries. The main economic activities include a free trading zone and a cement factory. This area, like nearly all impoverished areas of the Dominican Republic, suffers from unreliable running water (none of which is potable) and electricity.

loans.use: to buy ingredients

loans.name: Rubelyn

texts.en:
Rubelyn L. is from the town of Talibon. She is 30 years old, married and has 2 children. She is a fish vendor. She buys directly from fishermen and sells the fish at the market. Her husband is also a fisherman. Rubelyn is also happy that she now has a small sari-sari store where she sells various products in her community. She hopes for her ventures to prosper.

Rubelyn joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rubelyn has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. She is requesting a new loan of 25,000 PHP which will be used to buy more fish and additional store inventory. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the businesses to make improvements to her house.

loans.use: to buy more fish and additional inventory for her sari-sari store

loans.name: Ismael

texts.es: El señor Ismael M. Sánchez tiene un negocio de la venta de ropa usada desde hace 4 años establecido donde variedad de gente recurre. En su venta el cuenta con ropa de todas tallas, calzado y artículos para el hogar de segunda mano. El requiere de un crédito para surtir el negocio ya que viene la temporada de frío el quiere estar preparado para seguir ofreciendo mejor calidad.
texts.en: Mr. Ismael Martinez S. has had a business selling used clothes for 4 years, in a location with lots of traffic. His shop features clothing of all sizes, shoes, and second-hand household items. He needs a loan to stock his business for the cold weather season so he will be prepared to continue offering better quality items.

loans.use: to buy merchandise for his business

loans.name: Arlyn

texts.en:
Arlyn T. lives in Kalumboyan, Bayawan City, Negros Oriental. She earns her living by operating two business ventures: farming and selling rice.  Her common-law husband Mario Magbanua, who is 44 years old, works as a farmer to earn his living and helps in his wife's business activities.  She has three children who are 3 to 6 years old. Arlyn joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2008 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past four loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Arlyn has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 10,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 2,500, uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her fifth loan, she is borrowing PHP 13,000, which she intends to use to purchase farming equipment and tools so that she can continue to save up for the future education of her children. Arlyn T. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by joining the NWTF Kiva lending team at Kiva.org.

loans.use: To purchase farming equipment

loans.name: Elena

texts.es:
Elena tiene 46 años, es casada y vive en la ciudad del Cusco, ella desde hace mucho tiempo que participa en el banco comunal “La Unión” de la Unidad de Micro finanzas Arariwa. Elena alterna sus actividad del hogar con el pequeño negocio que tiene, ella tiene en su domicilio un establecimiento donde expende comestibles como por ejemplo arroz, fideos, azúcar, leche en tarro y muchas cosas más. 

Elena con su próximo préstamo que espera recibir de S/. 200 nuevos soles, ella invertirá el dinero para aumentar el capital del negocio y desea comprar mercadería como por ejemplo champagne, panetones, gallentas para la época navideña que se está acercando. 

La socia se encuentra agradecida por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma.
texts.en:
Elena is 46 years old, married and lives in the city of Cusco.  She has been a member of Arariwa's “La Unión” community bank for a long time.  She has a store in her home where she sells groceries such as rice, noodles, sugar, tinned milk and a lot more besides.

Elena will use her loan for 200 nuevos soles to increase her business capital and to buy goods such as champagne, panettones and cookies for the approaching Christmas holiday period.

She is grateful for the opportunity which she is being given with this loan and therefore pledges to make her repayments in a timely manner.

loans.use: To buy goods such as champagne, panettones and cookies for the approaching Christmas holiday period

loans.name: Janet

texts.en:
Janet N. lives in the Kamwokya neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is married and has five children; four of them are in school.  She also takes care of her father.    

Janet sells secondhand bed sheets and mattress covers  She has been in this business for 5 years, and she works 7 days a week, retailing her  products in a shop.  Janet has requested a loan of 300,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bales of bed sheets and mattress covers. Janet's main business challenges for Janet include seasonality and transportation.  Her goals and aspirations for her business are to start selling wholesale only and to buy a plot of land.   Janet lives in a home that she rents.  She doesn't have access to electricity or  piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include school fees, food and rent.

loans.use: To buy more bales of bed sheets and mattress covers

loans.name: Renacer Group

texts.es:
EL GRUPO RENACER SE INCIÓ HACE UN AÑO Y MEDIO SUS OCHO PARTICIPANTES HAN DEMOSTRADO HASTA EL MOMENTO RESPONSABILIDAD Y DESEOS D. SUPERARSE CADA UNO EN SU NEGOCIO YA SEA DEPENDIENTE O INDEPENDIENTE PERO TODAS COINCIDEN NO SOLO EN DAR LO MEJOR A LOS SUYOS SINO TAMBIÉN SUPERSE DÍA A DÍA TAL ES EL CASO D.:
LIDIA ES UNA MUJER QUE APRENDIÓ A TRABAJAR HACE DOCE AÑOS COMO MICROEMPRESARIA A  RAÍZ QUE SU ESPOSO LO DESPIDEN D. LA EMPRESA EN DOND. TRABAJABA. SE LAS INGENIÓ EN CONFECCIONAR CHOMPAS, COJINES HECHAS A PALITO Y LANA LO QUE LE AYUDÓ A SOLVENTAR LA ALIMENTACIÓN A SUS HIJOS AÚN MENORES D. EDAD, AÚN INSUFICIENTE LOS INGRESOS DECID. ADEMÁS VENDER PRODUCTOS D. BELLEZA; LAS VENTAS D. LOS TEJIDOS ERAN BUENOS HASTA QUE SE VE AFECTABA CON LA LLEGADA DEL FENÓMENO DEL NIÑO QUE CAUSÓ PÉRDINAS DEBIDO AL CAMBIO CLIMÁTICO INESPERADO (VERANO). NO DERROTADA AÚN COMO NOS CUENTA TUVO LA GRAN IDEA D. PREPARAR EN SU CASA RICOS DULCES TAL COMO MAZAMORRA MORADA, KEKES, TORTA D. CHOCOLATE Y VAINILLA; ADEMÁS D. PAPA CON HUEVO, PAPA CON OCOPA O PAPA CON CREMA A LA HUANCAINA. SUS POSTRES ERAN LLEVADOS EN UNA FUENTE O EN OLLAS LO CUAL PARA VENDERLOS TENÍA QUE CAMINAR LARGAS CUADRAS OFRECIENDO A LOS MERCADOS, TIENDAS, MECÁNICA D. AUTOS, FERRETERÍAS QUE CON EL TIEMPO CAPTÓ MÁS CONSUMIDORES POR EL TRATO Y SABOR EN LOS PRODUCTOS QUE HACÍA EN CASA. ES ASÍ QUE LIDIA SE CAPACITÓ MÁS EN REPOSTERÍA Y SE DIO CUENTA QUE LO HACÍA MUY BIEN. ACTUALMENTE PREPARA TORTAS PARA DISTINTOS EVENTOS O COMPROMISOS SOCIALES TALES COMO TORTA PARA QUINCEAÑOS, MATRIMONIO, BABY SHOWER, FIESTA D. GRADUACIÓN D. COLEGIOS, CUMPLEAÑOS U OTRO QUE LE SOLICITEN; ESTO HA SIDO BASTANTE BUENO PARA ELLA SIN IMAGINAR QUE LOS INGRESOS D. ESTAS VENTAS SIRVIERON NO SOLO PARA AFRONTAR LA  DIFÍCIL SITUACIÓN ECONÓMICA SINO TAMBIEN D. DAR A SUS HIJOS EDUCACIÓN TÉCNICA QUE ERA D. UNO D. SUS SUEÑOS ANHELADO. ESPERA QUE ELLOS COMPLEMENTEN SUS ESTUDIOS TÉCNICOS EN UNA UNIVERSIDAD Y ESTAR AL NIVEL D. LOS COMPETIDORES D. SU ESPECIALIDAD. LIDIA INVERTIRÁ EL CRÉDITO EN PRODUCTOS D. BELLEZA E INSUMOS PARA HACER TORTA D. PROMOCIÓN PUES TIENE PEDIDOS PENDIENTES PARA LA GRADUACIONES D. ESTUDIANTES EN COLEGIO. LIDIA ES LA SEGUNDA D. LA DERECHA Y VISTE BLUSA A RAYAS.
texts.en:
The “Renacer” (To Be Reborn) group started a year and a half ago.  Its 8 members have shown to date responsibility and the desire for self improvement each in her own business, either dependently or independently.  All, however, coinciD. in giving only the best to their loved ones and to improve daily.  Such is the case of:  Lidia who learned how to work as a micro businesswoman 12 years ago when her husband was laid off from his job.  

She figured out how to make knitted wool sweaters and cushions which helped her feed her children who are still minors.  Since income was still insufficient, she decided to also sell beauty products.  The sale of knitted items was good until the El Niño weather phenomenon arrived affecting it and causing losses due to the unexpected weather change (summer).  Not being defeated, however, as she tells us, she had the great idea to make delicious sweets at home like Mazamorra Morada (jelly-like dessert maD. from purple maize), Bundt cakes, chocolate and vanilla cakes.  She also maD. potatoes with eggs, potato and ocopa (potato with peanut sauce) or potato with cream.  She would take her desserts either on trays or in pots to sell them.  She had to walk long blocks to sell in markets, stores, car repair shops, hardware stores.  In time, she acquired more customers thanks to the good service and taste of her home maD. products.

Lidia then became better trained in pastry making and realized she did it quite well.  She now makes cakes for all occasions and social events like fifteen-year birthday parties, weddings, baby showers, school graduation parties, birthdays or any other one she is asked to do.  This has been very good for her.  She never imagined that income from these sales would serve not only to face the difficult economic situation but also to proviD. her children with technical education which was one of her fondest dreams.  She hopes that they will finish their technical studies at a university to be at the same level as their competition in their specialties.

Lidia will use the loan to buy beauty products and cake making supplies on sale because she has several pending orders for school graduation events.

Lidia is second from the right and is wearing a striped blouse.

loans.use: To buy ingredients for tortas and to buy beauty products.

loans.name: Jesus Divino Amor Group

texts.es:
Los socios pertenecen al banco comunal “JESUS DIVINO AMOR”; Este banco se ubicada en el distrito de Cusco, perteneciente a la provincia de Cusco y departamento de Cusco.

La socia es la Sra. Zoraida; ella tiene 38 años de edad y es casada y tiene 3 hijos; La socia se dedica al negocio de tienda de abarrotes, ella vende licores, champanes y panetones, ella necesita vender estos productos para la época navideña, ella atiende desde las 8:00 a.m hasta las 7:00 p.m, la socia quiere ampliar y mejorar el negocio de productos. La socia solicita el préstamo para comprar panetones, licores y champanes.

Los otros socios  se dedican a la venta de pasteles, venta de productos de golosina, venta de cueros, trabajo en computadora.

La socia está feliz por el préstamo y se compromete a cumplir con los pagos de su cuota.
texts.en:
These members belong to the “JESUS DIVINO AMOR” communal bank. This communal bank is located in the Cusco district, in the Cusco province and department.

This member is Zoraida. She is 38 years old, married and she has three children. Zoraida has a grocery store. She sells liquor, champagne and panettones. She needs to sell these products for the Christmas season. She works from 8:00am to 7:00pm. She wants to expand and improve her business. This member is requesting a loan to buy liquor, panettones and champagne.

The other other members sell cakes, sweets, leather products and work with computers.

Zoraida is happy about the loan and she promises to repay it on time.

loans.use: to buy liquor, panettones and champagne

loans.name: Santa Librada Group

texts.es:
Este comité se formó en el Barrio Constitución de la  Ciudad de Caaguazú, son 15 (Quince) señoras trabajadoras, solidarias y responsables, que decidierón formar un grupo de mujeres, cuyo fin es recibir un pequeño préstamo DE la Fundación Paraguaya para invertir en sus trabajos diarios,con el deseo de incrementar las ventas y recibir más ganancia para beneficio personal y de toda la familia.
Una de las integrantes es la señora quin se dedica a la señora Erma y se dedica a la venta de ropas.
Las ropas que ella vende los compra de Asuncion donde los precios son mucho mas baratos y actualmente solicita le prestamo para la compra de remeras, shors, blusas, vestidos y otros.
texts.en: The Santa Librada group was formed in the Constitución neighborhood of the Caaguazú city. It consists of fifteen hardworking, committed, and responsible women that decided to form a group whose goal is to receive a small loan from Fundación Paraguaya. The members would like to invest the loans into their daily jobs so that they could increase their sales and profits and thus have greater income for themselves and their families. Erma is one of the group's members. Erma works in clothing sales; she buys her inventory in the town of Asuncion where the prices are much lower and is currently seeking a loan to purchase T-shirts, shorts, blouses, dresses, and other items.

loans.use: Purchase of T-shirts, shorts, dresses, blouses, and other items.

loans.name: Bertha

texts.es:
Bertha tiene 37 años D. edad, es madre soltera y resiD. junto a su menor hija en el distrito agrícola D. TambogranD., una zona semitropical que produce principalmente frutas como el mango, el limón y la maracuyá. La localidad pertenece a la región Piura y se encuentra situada a más D. cuatro horas D. la ciudad D. Chiclayo, capital D. la región Lambayeque.

Bertha se dedica a la venta D. productos cosméticos por catálogo, ella trabaja en base a pedidos, ofreciendo sus productos a sus clientes (en su mayoría vecinos y conocidos), el pedido le llega los fines D. mes y ella gana dinero D. acuerdo a la cantidad D. pedidos que realice. Adicionalmente trabaja como vendedora en una ferretería D. la zona. Bertha  se vale D. estas dos actividades para ayudar a su hija a salir adelante.

Bertha desea adquirir productos con cuenta propia para poder contar con un stock fijo que le permita satisfacer rápidamente la demanda con la que cuenta, sin tener que llegar a fin D. mes, por ello ha creído conveniente solicitar a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito D. 1500 nuevos soles que le ayuden con el logro D. su objetivo.
texts.en:
Bertha is 37 years old.  She is a single mother and lives together with her youngest daughter in the agricultural district of TambogranD., a semi-tropical area that mainly produces fruit such as mangoes, lemons and passion fruit.  It is located in Piura region, more than four hours from the city of Chiclayo, capital of Lambayeque region.

Bertha sells cosmetics through a catalog.  She takes orders, offering her products to her customers (mainly neighbors and acquaintances).  Her goods arrives at the end of the month and she earns money according to how many orders she has taken.  Bertha also works as a saleswoman in a local hardward store.  She uses the income from these two activities to help her daughter get ahead in life.

Bertha would like to acquire products with her own money so that she can have a fixed stock that will allow her to quickly satisfy the demand she has without having to wait until the end of the month.  For this reason, she is requesting a loan for 1,500 Peruvian soles from Edpyme Alternativa that will help her achieve her goal.

loans.use: To buy cosmetics to expand her business

loans.name: Alberta

texts.en:
Alberta L. has been engaged in rice farming for quite a long time now. Though she is already 62, she is very capable of running a business.

With her 20 years of experience as a farmer, it is her hope that she will be able to expand her harvest and have a bigger farm. In that way, she will be able to help with her family's basic necessities.

She would like to apply for a loan at CEVI. The loan will help her buy fertilizers, chemicals and seeds. By doing this, she thinks she can do something to improve the harvest of her rice farm.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers, chemicals and seeds

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To complete his shop

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buying beer to sell

loans.name: Sally

texts.en:
Sally N. lives in the Kifumbira neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is married and has four children, all of whom are in school. They live in a home that she rents where she has access to electricity and to piped water.  Her major monthly expense is rent.

Sally has a business of selling Irish potatoes and tomatoes from home. Her main business challenge is seasonality. She has been in this business for six years, and she works seven days out of every week. She earns additional income from her dry cleaning business. 

She has requested a loan of 400,000 UGX from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more potatoes and tomatoes to sell.

loans.use: To buy more bags of Irish potatoes and baskets of tomatoes to sell

loans.name: Sthandokuhle Group

texts.en:
Vitress is 55 years old, and married with six children, three of whom attend school. She also takes care of two grandchildren. She earns an income from the government's child support grant. In the photo above she is wearing a white head scarf sitting in front of her group.

She has been in business for ten years and sells clothing, fruit and vegetables in town. She says the main challenges to her business are customers who buy on credit and do not pay on time.

She requested this loan through WDB and Kiva. She said that the extra income from this loan will help her extend her house and send her children for tertiary education. In the future she would like to see her business grow and become a fruit and vegetable supplier.

She also mentioned that she really appreciates WDB and Kiva for providing the loan.

loans.use: to buy clothing, fruits and vegetables.

loans.name: Munah

texts.en:
Munah is 40 years old and lives in the town of West Point. She is single and has four children aged 30, 25, 17 and 16. Only the two youngest live with her and are attending school. 

Munah cooks and sells rice and soup by the bowl, she has been doing this for 20 years. She says sometimes the business is very good and she has good profits and sometimes it's slow and she doesn't make any money. She started the business with money from her husband. 

Munah has requested a loan to buy rice, meat, pepper and other ingredients. In the future, she wants to build a house for her children.

loans.use: buy rice, meat, pepper and other ingredients

loans.name: Evelyn's Group

texts.en:
Evelyn M. is from the village of Malalinta. She is 43 years old. Evelyn is the group leader of a 6-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Evelyn M.'s Group.

Evelyn is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Evelyn owns & operates a general store selling a variety of different products to the local community. Evelyn has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2008, Evelyn joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 18,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. 

Evelyn is requesting a new loan of 20000 PHP to purchase more groceries inventory to sell. This will be her 7th loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay tuition fees for her children. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional groceries to sell

loans.name: Edson

texts.en: Edson lives in Uganda, is 36 years old and is applying for a loan to buy manure for his tea plantation. He lives in an area known as Kyenjojo, has six children who range in age from 15 years to one month, and dreams of providing all of them with an education. He has been farming for 10 years and has put a great deal of time and energy into caring for his plantation and building a house for his family. In the future, he would like to buy more equipment for his farm.

loans.use: To buy manure for his tea plantation

loans.name: Narandelger

texts.en:
Narandelger is 28 years old and lives with his wife and son in an apartment in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia.  His wife is a hairdresser who also cares for their 2-year-old son.  Narandelger manages a cell phone repair and trade business at a rented stall in the Narantuul market, one of the biggest markets in Mongolia.  He started his business in 2009 and has gained useful experience. He has been able to stabilize his business and build a strong customer base. 

Narandelger requests a 2,500,000 MNT loan to purchase more cell phones and cell phone parts for his business.  He plans to expand his business and have his own store in the future.  Narandelger is an open-minded man who possesses excellent managerial skills. He says, "I want to have my own store."

loans.use: To purchase more cell phones and cell phone parts

loans.name: Victoriana

texts.en:
Victoriana is 52 years old and has six children.  Victoriana is married and has two children who are in school.

Victoriana is in the agricultural business raising pigs in the Philippines.  Victoriana requested a PHP 10,000 loan through NWTF to buy feed and piglets.

Victoriana has been raisig pigs for 5 years now, and has borrowed 4 times in the past from NWTF to sustain it.

In the future, Victoriana would like to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy feed and piglets

loans.name: Galo Evaristo

texts.es:
Galo Evaristo tiene 42 años, es soltero vive con los padres no tiene hijos. Vive en El Cantón Ventanas Provincia de Los Ríos.

Esta Ventanilla se llama 27 DE OCTUBRE, se encuentra ubicada en el Recinto San Sofia, pertewneciente al Canton Ventanas, esta ventanilla se dedica a labores agricolas deciclo corto siembra de maiz, arroz, frejol gandul.

Galo se dedica a la agricultura en especial a la siembra de maíz, arroz, frejol. Las comprar las realiza en Ventanas cada mes y las vende en la feria de la misma localidad.

Solicita el crédito para la compra de semillas, fertilizantes y abonos.  Con el apoyo del crédito le ayudaría económicamente para suplir sus necesidades. Enfrentar desafíos como plagas y enfermedades en los cultivos. Su sueño es tener casa propia y terrenos.

Le gusta hacer deporte y caminar con los padres.
texts.en:
Galo Evaristo is 42 years old, single and lives with his parents, he has no children. He lives in the Ventanas area, province of Los Ríos.

The communal bank is called October 27, it is located in the San Sofia neighborhood, part of the Ventanas area, they work in short cycle agriculture corn, rice, and pigeon peas.

Galo works in agriculture, especially in corn, rice and beans. He buys his items each month in Ventanas and sells them in the market in the same area.

He needs the loan to buy seeds, fertilizers and manure. The support from the loan will help him to meet his economic needs. Galo faces different challenges like plagues and diseases that hurt his crops. His dream is to have his own home and land.

He enjoys sports and walking with his parents.

loans.use: buy seeds, fertilizers and manure.

loans.name: Tessie

texts.en:
Tessie is married and works hard to support her family. For the past seventeen years she has had a meat market in the Philippines.

Tessie has requested a 29,500 PHP loan through NWTF to purchase more meat to sell. She would like to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase more meat to sell.

loans.name: María Transito

texts.es:
La Señora María es socia del banco comunal Nueva Vida, vive por los alrededores de la ciudad  de Cuenca, sector donde su gente se dedica a la agricultura y crianza de animales, muchos encuentran en sus negocios las fuentes de trabajo y sustento para sus familias.

Doña María tiene 53 años de edad, es casada y en su unión conyugal ha concebido 7 hijos, tres de sus hijos trabajando para sus gastos personales, dos de sus hijos  estudian en la universidad y sus dos últimos hijos están en un colegio de la ciudad. Su esposo ha migrado en busca de un mejor trabajo, no tiene casa propia por lo que vive en casa de un familiar. 

La Señora. María trabaja en la agricultura, lo que cosecha para su consumo y para la venta. También tiene una fábrica de ladrillos en la que trabaja hace 20 años de lunes a viernes sin un horario fijo.

Se encuentra reingresando al banco comunal y su crédito lo va a invertir en la compra de arcilla para fabricar sus ladrillos.

Su sueño sería no tener deudas.
texts.en:
Maria is a member of the Nueva Vida village bank. She lives on the outskirts of the city of Cuenca, an area where the people work in agriculture and animal husbandry, businesses which are the sources of work and sustenance for many families. 

Maria is 53 years old, married and has 7 children. 3 of her children work and are independent; two are studying at university; and the last two are in a local high school. Her husband has moved in search of better work. They don't own their home, so they live with relatives. 

Maria works in agriculture. Some of her harvest goes to feed her family, and the rest is sold. She also has a brick factory where she has worked for 20 years, Monday to Friday without a fixed schedule. 

She finds herself re-entering the village bank and will invest her loan in the purchase of clay to make her bricks.

Her dream is to be debt-free.

loans.use: to buy clay to make bricks.

loans.name: Veronica

texts.en:
Veronica is a 44-year-old married lady and has one child aged 18. She runs a tailoring business where she makes and sells clothes to local people in Thika. She has been in this business for 15 years now and hires two employees. She says that the business is profitable and her major challenge is the low purchasing power of the local people.
Veronica is using her loan of 50,000 KES to buy materials to grow her business and meet the demands of her customers. She hopes to grow her business and diversify by building rental houses. She describes herself as hardworking, focused and patient.

loans.use: to purchase materials for her tailoring business.

loans.name: Teodora

texts.en: Teodora is 42 years old and married with three children. She earns a living by farming rice in the Philippines. Teodora is borrowing 19,000 Philippine pesos through NWTF to buy fertilizers and other farm supplies. Teodora has been farming rice for five years and also earns additional income from a sari-sari store. She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream: to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and other farm supplies.

loans.name: La Esperanza Group

texts.es:
El comité La Esperanza, es de la ciudad de Lambaré, actualmente está integrado por 13 mujeres, todas ellas amigas y vecinas de esa ciudad. Las señoras integrantes del comité se destacan por el sacrificio y las ganas de progresar, muchas de ellas son madres solteras que inician su día a día desde muy tempranas horas, saliendo a recorrer las calles para hacer su ventas. Comentan que se unieron con el propósito de poder seguir creciendo económicamente, como así también en lo personal.
La señora Balbina se dedica a la venta de ropas usadas. Ella lleva bastante tiempo en este trabajo y comenta que tiene muchos clientes, lo cual le genera a su vez buenos ingresos. Ella se define como una mujer muy trabajadora, honesta y responsable. Comenta que todo lo que realiza es por darle un mejor estilo de vida a su familia. Uno de sus sueños es poder tener un local propio donde pueda traer más prendas para vender y de esa forma atraer a más clientes.
Ella solicita el crédito para la compra de prendas de segunda mano, para la posterior venta. Agradece a la Fundación por la oportunidad que esta le brinda, ya que de obtener el crédito le será de gran ayuda.
texts.en:
The communal bank La Esperanza is in the city of Lambaré. Currently it is comprised of 13 women, all are friends and neighbors in that city. The women who make up the communal bank stand out because of their sacrifice and desire to succeed. Many of them are single mothers who begin their day in the early hours, leaving to walk the streets to make their sales throughout all of Asuncion, Paraguay's capital. 

Balbina sells used clothes. She has worked for quite some time in this business, and she notes that she has many clients which in turn generates a lot of income. She sees herself as a woman who is very hard-working, honest, and responsible. She says that everything she does is to give her family a better quality of life. She is asking for a loan to buy second hand clothes for later resale. She thanks the Fundación for this unique opportunity, as receiving this loan will be a great help.

loans.use: Compra de prendas de segunda mano para la posterior venta

loans.name: Precy

texts.en:
Precy is 45 years old and is married to local farmer. They live together in Dalaoig, Alcala. The couple was blessed with two children, both of whom are attending secondary school. For almost ten years, Precy and her husband have cultivated a one-hectare rice field. 

Precy does not have sufficient funds to sustain her farm and therefore she is requesting a 10,000 PHP loan to buy seeds, fertilizer, and pay labor costs to cultivate the land. This loan will enable her to sustain her crop. During the previous harvest season in May, Precy and her family earned about 40,000 PHP which went to pay school fees and buy groceries for daily meals.

In the future, Precy would like to earn consistent profits and save for the college education of her two children.

loans.use: to buy seeds and fertilizer and hire field labor

loans.name: Carlos Andres

texts.es:
Carlos tiene 32 años tiene 3 hijos vive con su mamá en San Gabriel, se describe como una persona tranquila, luchadora y le gusta siempre salir adelante.

Carlos trabaja en la compra venta de ganado. Es el tercer crédito que le solicita a Fodemi el mismo que será utilizado para la compra de terneros para su crianza y venta, lo cual mejoraría su calidad de vida y la de su familia.

Su sueño es tener un terreno propio para poder criar a sus terneros.
texts.en:
Carlos, 32, has three children and lives with his mother in San Gabriel.  He describes himself as a quiet person and a fighter who always likes to get ahead.

Carlos buys and sells cattle.  This is the third loan that he himself has requested from FODEMI.  He will use it to buy calves to raise and sell, which would improve his quality of life and that of his family.

His dream is to have his own piece of land to be able to raise his calves.

loans.use: to buy calves.

loans.name: Ofelia

texts.en:
Ofelia is 35 years old and has been engaged in the piggery business for five years. She says that this occupation is not easy; however, because of the determination and inspiration that her children provide, she does everything for the benefit of their underprivileged lifestyle.

Ofelia is asking for a loan of PHP 30,000 to provide for the needs of her pigs by giving them better feed and vitamins. She is patiently growing her business into a bigger venture. She hopes that someday she will achieve her dream and lift her family from poverty.

loans.use: to buy better pig feed and vitamins

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
Erlinda is 47 years-old and lives in the Philippines. She is married.

Erlinda has a shop that sells canned goods, snacks and beverages . She has had this business for ten years. She requested a loan of PHP 10,000 in order to buy canned goods, snacks and beverages to sell.

Erlinda has been a member of Kiva partner HSPFI since 2010. In the future, Erlinda hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, snacks and beverages to sell.

loans.name: Nidia Beatriz

texts.es:
La Sra. Nidia tiene 45 años D. edad, está casada, tiene dos hijos, vive en la ciudad D. Itá. Tiene un taller D. costura en su domicilio hace más D. 12 años, su marido trabaja en una empresa como chofer hace ya como 27 años. Ambos ayudan en los ingresos del hogar y gracias al trabajo en conjunto salen adelante.
Nidia es una mujer muy trabajadora, responsable y dedicada a sus hijos, ella cuenta que gracias a los préstamos que le otorgo la fundación creció y se formo en su microempresa. Ella tiene como objetivo que la empresa sea reconocida a nivel local ya que esto le ayudará a formarse como empresaria y aumentara el nivel económico D. ella y su familia.
Solicita la ayuda D. la fundación para la compra D. telas, el cual es el elemento indispensable para su negocio.
texts.en:
Sra. Nidia is 45 years old, married, and has two children. She lives in the city of Itá. Nidia has operated a sewing workshop in her home for more than 12 years. Her husband has worked for a company as a chauffeur for 27 years. Both of them help one another with the household expenses and they have been able to move forward because of their work.

Nidia is a hardworking and responsible woman who is dedicated to her children. She says that the loans from Fundación Paraguaya have helped her to grow and develop into a micro-entrepreneur. Nidia indicates that the goal for her business is to be recognized on a local level. This will help her become established as a businesswoman and increase the financial standing for herself and her family.

Nidia is requesting assistance from Fundación Paraguaya in order to buy fabric, an indispensable product for her business.

loans.use: to buy fabric.

loans.name: Anitah

texts.en:
Anitah is a 27-year-old lady who is blessed with one child, a one year old.  She sells cereals to earn a living.  She has been in the business for four years.  She has employed two people to assist her in her task.  She was previously employed as a shopkeeper and managed to open her own business through Faulu Kenya.

Anitah needs a loan of 50,000 Kenya shillings to buy cereals.

loans.use: To buy cereals.

loans.name: Pedro Alberto

texts.es:
El señor Pedro Alberto es originario de la ciudad de Veracruz y su esposa es originaria de la ciudad de México. Don Pedro Alberto elabora como guardia de seguridad escolar, y por las tardes El y su familia se dedican a recolectar productos para  reciclar como es plásticos y aluminio, y los fines de semana su esposa elaborar comida mexicano (menudo)  para vender y así ayudar a los gastos familiares, ya que cuentan con cuatro hijos de edad escolar, y desean sacar a delante a sus hijos y que tengan un mejor futuro. 
Solicitan el préstamo para comprar un triciclo, porque el que tiene actual ya esta en muy malas condiciones. Ya teniendo un nuevo podrán trasladar más fácil la mercancía.
texts.en: Pedro Alberto is from the city of Veracruz and his wife is from Mexico City.  Pedro works as a school security guard and in the afternoons he and his family collect recyclables like plastic and aluminum.  On weekends, his wife prepares Mexican food (menudo) to sell and help with household expenses because they have four school aged children and they want to raise their children so that they’ll have a better future.  They request the loan to buy a tricycle cart because the one he currently owns is in very poor condition.  Having a new one will make transporting the merchandise easier.

loans.use: to buy a tricycle cart to use for recycling.

loans.name: Keiry Patricia

texts.es:
La señora Keiry tiene 22 años de edad y vive con sus padres y dos hermanas en la aldea de Nuevo Jalapa en el municipio de Nuevo Celilac. Keiry es soltera y no tiene hijos. 

Keiry era enfermera en una hospital local pero hace 8 meses, con el apoyo de sus padres, ella decidió poner su propio negocio para no depender de otro para trabajo. Inició su pulpería en marzo y trabaja todos los días de 6:00 AM a 8:00 PM atendiendo su clientela. Vende productos alimenticios y todo lo que pertenece a la canasta básica. 

Solicitó este crédito de L10,000 para surtir su negocio con productos comestibles ya que se acerca la temporada de navidad y las ventas aumentan. Keiry espera crecer como comerciante para ayudar a sus padres y hermanas.
texts.en:
Señora Keiry is 22 years old and lives with her parents and two sisters in the village of Nuevo Jalapa  in the Nuevo Celilac municipality.  Keiry is single and has no children.

Keiry was a nurse at a local hospital, but 8 months ago, with the help of her parents, she decided to start up her own business so that she didn't need to depend on other people for employment.  She opened her convenience store in March, and works from 6 a.m. to 8 p.m. every day serving her customers.  She sells grocery items and everything needed for household basics.

She requested this loan of L10,000 to stock up her business with grocery products, as the Christmas season is nearing when her sales increase.  Keiry hopes to grow as a business woman, so that she can help support her parents and her sisters.

loans.use: for the purchase of grocery products.

loans.name: Liana

texts.en:
Liana is from the village Gvishtibi, West Georgia. She is 46-years-old, married and lives with her husband Shota. Shota is a tractor driver. He works on various agricultural projects on his and the neighbors' farms. Liana is leading the agricultural business of the family. They own a milk cow and 2 piglets. Liana produces cheese and sells it at the local market. The piglets are also sold in the village. Total average monthly income of the family is 600 Laris.

Liana requested credit for purchasing materials for a pig house and a cattle-shed renovation as these two buildings are in bad condition and need renovation to keep the needed temperature for domestic animals.

loans.use: to purchase materials for a pig house and a cattle-shed renovation.

loans.name: Catalina Maruja

texts.es:
La socia es la Sra. Catalina Maruja; tiene 58 años de edad, y es casada y tiene 5 hijos; La socia se sigue dedicando al negocio de venta de ropa,ella vende pantalones,polos,blusas y casaca para niños y ahora la socia tambien teje chompas a maquina y tambien lo vende en las tiendas que venden ropa para niños,por medio de este negocio la socia saca adelante a sus hijos,el sueño de la socia es ampliar el negocio de venta de ropa y negocio de tejido de chompas . La  socia solicita el préstamo para comprar ropa de niños como pantalones, polos y chompas y tambien para comprar lana.

 La socia agradece el préstamo solicitado  y se compromete a cumplir con el pago de sus cuotas en el plazo establecido.
texts.en:
The borrower is Catalina Maruja. She is 58, married, and has five children.  

She continues to sell clothing. She sells pants, T-shirts, blouses, and jackets for children, and now she also knits sweaters by machine, and also sells them in the stores that sell children's clothing. Through this business, she is raising her children. 

Her dream is to expand her business selling clothing, and her business of knitting sweaters. She is applying for the loan to buy children's clothing such as pants, T-shirts, and sweaters, and also to buy wool. 

She is grateful for the loan, and promises to make her instalment payments on time.

loans.use: To buy children's clothing, such as pants, T-shirts, and sweaters, and also to buy wool.

loans.name: Annie

texts.en: Annie is 59 years old, married with three children ages 14, 17 and 20. Annie does tailoring to earn a living. She has been in the business for 10 years and has employed two people. She earns extra income from her farming activities. She describes her business environment as busy because many people visit her daily. Since she joined Faulu Kenya, she has been able to educate her children. She has applied for 30,000 Kenya Shillings to buy cloth materials.

loans.use: to buy cloth materials

loans.name: Nicolás

texts.es:
Todos los días la vida de Nicolás transcurren en la práctica de una caminata diaria de 2 horas y esto no lo hace por Hobbie, aunque si con una gran alegría: Nicolás se desempeña en su negocio de vender los deliciosos y jugosos aguacates que le traen del Carmen, en el departamento de Bolívar y limones cultivados a lo largo del Rio Magdalena,  loa cuales traslada en una carretilla  rebosada  del  verde  color de estas  frutas, que entrega  directamente en las manos de sus clientes,  ubicados en una urbanización muy lejana cerca a las Playas de la ciudad. Nicolás se despierta bien temprano, llena su carretilla de aguacates y limones y se va a visitar a sus clientes; a ellos  los tiene acostumbrados a recibir las frutas  en la puerta de su casa, que entrega  mediante una conversación amena y muy Caribe.  Con esta actividad  ha logrado sacar adelante a su familia, conformada por su cónyuge y sus 4 hijos en las edades de 18 a 32 años. 
Nicolás fue educado por su abuela y desde los 13 años está trabajando, primero lo hizo vendiendo cocadas, o dulces elaborados a base de coco y/o guayaba, luego trabajó ayudando a los vendedores de frutas y posteriormente, cuando conformó su familia y con la suficiente experiencia, emprendió su sueño de ser independiente. Es por esto que desde hace 5 años, trabaja persistentemente en su propio negocio, teniendo como norte lograr bienestar para su familia, dispuesto a  que en un futuro “no pasen trabajo”, como el mismo lo dice. Como la meta  de Nicolás es tener un depósito o local donde conservar las frutas,  gradualmente necesita crecer, aumentando su clientela y su capacidad de comercialización. Esta es la razón por la cual acude a su credikiva, primer financiamiento que hace a la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, con el cual comprará en mayor volumen y de contado aguacates y limones, para disminuir los precios del producto, pues compra diario con dinero de crédito informal y altamente costoso y con ello para poder sostenerse,  incrementa el precio del producto, razón por la cual está en condiciones desiguales en el mercado; esto es posible solucionarlo con credikiva ,  financiación que planea seria exitosa porque aprovecharía  los costos de  oportunidad,  debido a que  tendría un capital para negociar  por volúmenes y de contado y lograría acceder a precios de productos sostenibles, que así mismo trasladará a sus clientes, haciendo que su negocio  sea mas competitivo.
texts.en:
Every day, Nicolás’s life includes a daily 2-hour walk and he doesn’t do this as a hobby although he does do it joyfully.  Nicolás sells delicious, juicy avocadoes that they bring him from El Carmen in Bolívar Department and lemons farmed along the Magdalena River which he transports in a wheelbarrow lush with the green color of these fruits that he delivers directly into the hands of his customers located in a settlement quite far from the city’s beaches.    Nicolás wakes up very early, fills up his wheelbarrow with avocadoes and lemons and heads out to visit his customers.  He has accustomed them to receive their fruit at their doorsteps, a delivery he carries out with a very enjoyable, Caribbean conversation.  With this activity he’s managed to support his family which consists of his spouse and four children ranging in age from 18 to 32.

Nicolás was educated by his grandmother and has been working since he was 13 years old.  First he worked selling ‘cocadas,’ candy made from coconut and/or guava.  Then he worked helping fruit merchants and still later when he formed his own family and with the gained experience, he started his dream of being independent.  Because of this, for the last five years he has worked persistently in his own business his guiding star being is family’s wellbeing.  As he himself says, he’s determined that they should “not have to go through struggles” in the future.

Since Nicolas’s goal is to have a warehouse or depository to keep his fruit, he gradually needs to grow increasing his clientele and his capacity for sales.  This is why he’s calling on a Kiva loan, his first financing with Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, that he will use to pay cash for larger amounts of avocadoes and lemons so he can reduce the price he pays since he currently buys daily with money from informal loans which is extremely expensive but this is the way he’s be able to stay in business but the price of his products increases leaving him at a disadvantage in the marketplace.  All of this can be solved with a Kiva loan, financing he hopes will be successful because he will be able to take advantage of special promotional prices because he’ll have capital with which to negotiate cash payments for volume purchases thus obtaining sustainable product prices that he can pass on to his customers making his business more competitive.

loans.use: to pay cash for large amounts of avocadoes and lemons.

loans.name: Casse Auto 1 Group

texts.fr: CASSE AUTO 1 est un groupe de trois personnes, dont les membres résident dans le même quartier. La représentante du groupe, Éléonore Abla (dont la main est levée sur la photo), âgée de 35 ans ne vit plus avec son mari.Éléonore Abla est mère de trois enfants, tous scolarisés et à la charge du couple. Éléonore Abla vit seule avec ses enfants. Éléonore Abla a arrêté l’école au niveau secondaire. Les diverses charges de la maison sont supportées par le couple. Pour ce faire, Éléonore Abla vend de façon ambulante des cartes de recharges téléphoniques et des boissons. Éléonore Abla s’approvisionne dans un marché du Bénin. C’est la deuxième fois que Éléonore Abla et les autres membres du groupe CASSE AUTO 1 sollicitent l’appui financier de ALIDé en vue de renforcer leur fonds de roulement et leur activité et de mieux répondre aux exigences de leur clientèle. Le crédit reçu antérieurement a été bien remboursé.

loans.use: Acheter des cartes de recharges téléphoniques.

loans.name: Luxmi Group One

texts.en: Kiranmala is a 38 year old married woman. She lives with her family of 4 in Imphal East district of Manipur state in the Eastern part of India. She has a cloth shop where she sells shawls, phaneks, salwars, kurtas etc. This enterprising woman is seeking a loan to expand her clothing business by purchasing more stock and looking to increase her sales which eventually will result in more income. The other members of the group are also engaged in various income generation activities like cloth selling, tailoring and embroidery work. All the members of the group will use the loan to buy more stock and raw materials to expand their respective businesses. Therefore, they all joined hands to form the group and applied for a loan for upgrading their businesses. They are well aware of the group rules and agreed to abide by them. They are thankful to the lenders for their support.

loans.use: To purchase more stock for her cloth store selling shawl, salwar, kurta etc.

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
Maria B. has owned her business for 3 years. She sells men’s and women’s clothes door-to-door in a part of Guayaquil called Mapasingue. She originally started out with the help of her son who loaned her $200. Every day she works from 9am until 5pm selling her clothes to neighbors, friends, and shoppers near the local bazaar. Maria has a second source of income from cleaning clothes for a family two days a week. She is applying for this loan through Kiva and Mifex so that she can afford marketing materials and better equipment for transporting her goods in a presentable fashion. The months of November and December are particularly important because most families buy gifts during the holidays and prepare for the new year. This 41 year-old from Manabi, Ecuador has three children and is married to a loving husband who helps out with the business. 

Mifex offers its clients microinsurance and access to business training and educational programs. For more information about microfinance, Ecuador, and our services, please visit www.mifex.org.

loans.use: She is applying for this loan through Kiva and Mifex so that she can afford marketing materials and better equipment for transporting her goods in a presentable fashion.

loans.name: Onofa

texts.en: Onofa is a 40 year old mother with 4 sons; two are employed at Salani Reef Resort, one is a policeman, and one lives at home working in his father’s plantation.  Onofa’s business is a grocery shop that was developed from her husband’s plantation.  Back then, before she joined SPBD, she was only able to buy some goods that they could afford, mostly rice, sugar, tea, mosquito oil, noodles, soap and toilet tissues.  It’s now Onofa’s third loan and there has been a big improvement with her business.  She’s now selling different a variety of goods, candies, snacks, soft drinks, beer, cigarettes, frozen foods, fruit etc.  With her requested loan, she plans to extend her shop because with her business growing she is not able to fit into the small space she has now.

loans.use: To purchase additional goods and inventory for her retail shop and for expansion of her store space

loans.name: Mukaram

texts.en: Mukaram, a woman with one child and a university degree, has been in business for over 13 years. Her husband is her business partner. He is responsible for trips to the wholesale market, and sometimes she accompanies him to make sure he chooses the suitable items.  She sells mainly sports clothes, which are in high demand by young people. Mukaram rents a place at the “Nuri Khujand,” which is not far away from her town's central market. She would like to rent one more place where she could sell clothes for teenage boys. She already has the money for rent and a portion of the money for goods. She will use the $1,200 to travel to the wholesale market.

loans.use: Trip to wholesale market

loans.name: Eam

texts.en: Mrs. Eam N. is 28 years old and is a widow who lives with her mother and her child in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. She is a diligent mother who works very hard to support the entire family. She makes her living by selling different kinds of tires in her area and typically makes around $5/day. Recently, Eam N. can no longer satisfy all her clients' needs, but she is not able to increase her inventory, which is why she needs the loan to help her.

loans.use: To purchase more tires in order to meet her clients' needs.

loans.name: Ha Thi

texts.vi:
Quang Khe is a poor village in the southern Quang Xuong district of Thanh Hoa province. People there have difficult lives. Since they do not easily get capital funds from the government or the banks, they often have to borrow money with a high rate of interest from loan sharks. In 2003, TYM Fund opens a branch in this village and starts to lend the villagers money using microfinance. Mrs. Ha Thi C.’s family has become a member of TYM Fund since then. At the age of 40, she is confident to borrow at the maximum limit. She uses the fund on the right purpose and it clearly improves her life. This time she wants to borrow $400 to buy rush to make sedge mats. Besides working, Mrs. C. also spends a lot of time taking care of her parents. She goes to class every other night and makes sedge mats with her parents during the others. Everyday her family makes 2 mats, each is sold at $3.

Translated from Vietnamese by Phuong Nguyen, Kiva Volunteer.

Quảng Khê là một xã nghèo nằm phía Nam huyện Quảng Xương, Thanh Hóa. Đời sống người dân nơi đây gặp nhiều khó khăn, các nguồn vốn không đến được với ngưòi nghèo họ thường phải vay nặng lãi. Năm 2003 Quỹ TYM đã về với địa phương và thực hiện phương thức cho vay vốn trả theo tuần. Gia đình chị Hà Thị Chân đã tham gia Quỹ từ ngày đó. Năm nay 40 tuổi, sức khỏe còn rất tốt nên các vòng vốn chị đều vay tối đa. Nguồn vốn được sử dụng đúng mục đích nên mang lại hiệu quả rõ rệt. Vòng vốn này chị vay 400 USD để mua thêm lác dự trữ cho việc làm chiếu Các chị cũng tích cực hỗ trợ bố mẹ rất nhiều. Một buổi đi học, một buổi cùng bố mẹ dệt chiếu. Mỗi ngày gia đình chị dệt được 2 đôi chiếu, một đôi bán được 3 USD.

loans.use: buy rush to make sedge mats

loans.name: Hilda Maurina

texts.en:
Hilda Maurina M. C. belongs to the village bank called “Pura Vida,” which means “Pure Life” in Spanish.

Hilda, along with the rest of her family, open up their home on Sundays as a restaurant. With a big back patio, colorful umbrellas, and lots of green flora, Hilda’s restaurant has become a popular destination for families on their day of rest. Hilda and her mother are always in the kitchen cooking Peruvian favorites such as “puca,” a dish containing potatoes, peanuts, meat, and rice. Meanwhile, her sister and father are running the logistical side of things.

Although the restaurant keeps the family busy throughout the week, Hilda also has her own separate small business of fresh meat supply. Each Saturday, she wakes up very early to drive four hours and buy sheep, cows, and pigs. She then takes the animals to a nearby market and her customers request specific cuts of meat. The rest of the week is then spent selling any animals that are not sold immediately in the market.

Hilda says her dream is to one day open up her very own butcher shop, complete with a corral. She says she has done everything she can to support her four children, one grown, two in high school, and the other in elementary school. This is why she says she loves her village bank which has helped her to save money towards her goal. Hilda is requesting a US$ 700 loan which she will invert back into both of her businesses, buying ingredients for the restaurant and more animals for the market.

loans.use: buying ingredients for her restaurant and more animals for the market

loans.name: Christian Rural

texts.en:
Florence Adu – Gyamfi sells provisions (milk, milo, oaths, rice, biscuits, minerals, mineral water etc). She is married with three children ages 16, 12 and 8 years respectively. Her husband is a steel bender and his income is low. To help in the family finances, Florence works very hard. In addition to the provisions that she sells, she is also a seamstress and sows dresses for people whiles at her provision store.
Some of the challenges that she faces is that her hand sewing machine is old so she needs a new hand sewing machine to help her sow dresses more quickly for people since the old one that she is using gives her problems when sowing. Her stock is also going down because now, she has to make an advance payment before she receives supplies from her suppliers.
She is therefore asking for a loan of US $ 1,000 dollars to enable her make advance payment to her suppliers so that they can supply provisions such as milk, milo, nido, biscuits, sardines, mineral water, crates of minerals etc. and also, to purchase a new hand sewing machine. She intends paying the loan back within seven months.

loans.use: To buy a new hand sewing machine, fill the shop with provisions such as milk, milo, minerals, soap, mineral water etc.

loans.name: Teresa

texts.es:
I have had my beauty salon for more than 5 years. I mainly do haircuts and hairdos for men and women. I am in need of more furniture and equipment. This business is my family’s sole source of income. I am requesting this loan of $1,200.00 USD to buy beauty salon furniture and equipment.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer.

Tengo ya mas de 5 años con mi negocio de estética mas que nada me dedico al corte, peinados de damas y caballeros me esta haciendo falta mas inmobiliario y equipo. Este negocio es la fuente de ingreso de mi familia. Solicito un préstamo de $1,200.00 Dlls para la comprar de inmobiliario para le estética.

loans.use: Purchase of beauty salon furniture and equipment

loans.name: María Candelaria

texts.es:
María Candelaria is a mother of two daughters who are 14 and 17 years of age and one son who is 18 years old, to whom she always wishes to give the best. Currently, her eldest is studying and María wishes that he complete a university degree. As a result, two years ago, upon realizing that her husband’s salary was not enough to pay for her son’s university education, María began to sew for her friends and neighbors. Gradually, she has built a good reputation and now she has customers who ask her for all kinds of items, including costumes. Right now, she has an order for the Carnival celebrations and it requires an investment in fabric.

Nevertheless, she does not have enough material to fulfill this order. Consequently, María is soliciting a loan of US $200 which she will repay in 6 months. This will allow her to purchase the material she needs and deliver the costumes and earn more income. With your help, María will be able to advance her career and save some money for her children’s future expenses.

Translated from Spanish by Kate Divjak, Kiva volunteer.

María Candelaria es madre de dos niñas de 14 y 7 años y de un niño de 18 años, a quienes desea darles siempre lo mejor. Actualmente tiene al más grande estudiando, y María desea que termine una carrera universitaria. Fue por eso que hace 2 años al ver que con el sueldo de su esposo no podrían pagar la universidad de su hijo que María comenzó a coser para sus amigos y vecinos, poco a poco se ha ido haciendo conocida, ahora ya tiene clientes que le solicitan todo tipo de confección, incluso disfraces, precisamente ahora tiene un pedido para las fiestas de carnaval, y requiere invertir en tela para confeccionarlas.

Sin embargo no cuenta con material suficiente como para hacer ese pedido. Es por eso que María está solicitando un crédito de US $200 que está dispuesta a pagarlos en un plazo de 6 meses para poder comprar el material que necesita y así entregar los disfraces para que pueda recibir mayores ganancias. Con tu ayuda María podrá sacar adelante este trabajo, además de que con este dinero podrá ahorrar un poco para futuros gastos de sus hijos.

loans.use: Purchase raw material for her products.

loans.name: Pen

texts.en: Pen S., 38, works as a house wife looking after the children and cooking food for her family. Her husband, Em Sokunthea, 41, is a construction laborer who earns around $5 a day. They have three children, two of whom also labor in Kampong Cham province making on average $2 each a day. This couple hopes to borrow $600 to purchase clothes to sell in their village and also to raise pigs for extra profit.

loans.use: To purchase clothes to sell in the village and raise pigs for extra profit.

loans.name: Angelique

texts.en:
Angelique is 45 years old and is married with 3 children, ages 18, 15, and 10. Angelique owns a small food vending store, which she started in 2005. Every day she works from 7:00 AM to 5:00 PM at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $65 from her sales.

In the past, Angelique has taken out 2 successful loans from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She now hopes for a loan to buy more food items for her business.

loans.use: To buy more food items for her business

loans.name: Hoang Thi

texts.vi:
Mrs. Hoàng Thị Bình, 45 years old, joins the TYM Fund in 2002. She lives with her husband and their two children, one of them is still in school age. She used the funds from her first loan to invest in raising pigs for meat. The business prospered and she continues to take more loans to invest in poultry. After five years, now her family has a 5 room fully furnished house. At the present she has 80 chickens and 26 pigs ready for butcher shops. This time she would like to apply for a loan of 1200USD to invest livestock business.

Translated from Vietnamese by ngungo, Kiva volunteer.


Chị Hoàng Thị Bình, 45 tuổi, tham gia Quỹ năm 2002. Chị đang sống cùng chồng và 2 con, trong đó một cháu còn đi học. Vòng vốn đầu tiên chị Bình vay về đầu tư chăn nuôi lợn thịt. Công việc phát triển tốt cho thu nhập cao, chị Bình tiếp tục vay vốn chăn nuôi thêm gà thịt. Sau 5 năm tham gia, chị Bình đã làm được căn nhà ngói 5 gian khang trang và mua sắm đầy đủ tiện nghi sinh hoạt. Hiện tại gia đình chị đang nuôi 80 con gà thịt và 26 con lợn chuẩn bị xuất chuồng. Vòng vốn này chị Bình xin vay 1200USD để mua con giống và thức ăn gia súc.

loans.use: Buy pigs, chickens

loans.name: Rokia

texts.fr:
Mrs. S. Rokia is 29 and a married mother of three children. Like all women of her generation, Mrs. S. decided to earn her living through an income-generating business. She thus decided to sell cloth, which is an item in high demand among women in Mali. In the beginning, she lacked the funds to start her business, like all other women in Ségou. That was why she decided to join a group that received a loan from Soro Yiriwaso. All of her previous loans have been repaid in full. She purchases her items in Bamako, primarily from wholesalers. Her customers come to buy her cloth and then sew it to wear at important social events (marriages or baptisms). The quality of her products draws more customers than her competitors. With this loan, she would like to purchase 90 units of traditional African “Wax” cloth. She uses her profits to help feed her parents (namely her mother), to pay off the interest on her loan, for savings and to help pay her husband’s family’s expenses.

Translated from French by Kristina Jackson, Kiva Volunteer.

Madame S. Rokia est mariée de 29 ans et mère de trois enfants. Comme toutes les femmes de sa génération, Madame S., pour gagner sa vie, a décidé de mener une activité génératrice de revenus. Ainsi elle a décidé de faire le commerce de tissus très prisés par la population féminine du Mali. Au début elle a été confrontée à un problème de fonds de commerce pour mener son activité comme toutes les autres femmes de Ségou. C’est ainsi qu’elle intégra un groupe solidaire bénéficiant de prêt de la part de Soro Yiriwaso. Tous ses prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés. Elle s’approvisionne surtout à Bamako auprès de grossiste. Ses clients viennent acheter les tissus chez elle pour les coudre lors des cérémonies sociales (Mariage ou baptême). La qualité des articles vendus fait qu’elle attire plus de clients que les autres concurrents. Avec ce pret elle veut acheter 90 pagnes Wax. Son bénéfice est utilisé pour assurer les frais d’alimentation de sa famille paternelle notamment sa maman, pour payer les intérêts du prêt, épargner et participer aux charges de la famille de son mari.

loans.use: Purchase and sale of cloth

loans.name: Mustafa

texts.en: Mustafa Mlidwa is a 37 year old resident of the Chanika neighborhood of Dar es Salaam. He makes a living selling spare parts for bicycles, a business he has been in for the past five years. Bicycles are a common means of transport in this part of Dar es Salaam, and he has applied for a loan to expand his business.

loans.use: To expand his business

loans.name: Prosperidad Group

texts.es:
The Prosperity Committee formed as a union of neighbors in the Las Garzas neighborhood in the city of San Antonio. At first, the committee had bad experiences with the program, since they had some people who didn't fulfill their responsibilities, but now they have recuperated their confidence and their solidarity. Prosperity is one of the committees that has succeedeed with good organization and stability in this city. They are only on their fourth loan, but in this time they have demonstrated a lot of capacity to work as a team. In this photograph are 15 of the 16 members of the committee. All of the members have their own activities. Although some have formal jobs, they carry out their businesses in their extra time to increase their income. The committee has a very harmonious relationship among all of their members, and they have demonstrated their unity on various occasions. The carry out their activities as a group, such as solving any inconvenience by making a majority decision.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva volunteer

El Comitè “Prosperidad” se formò a partir de la union de vecinas del barrio Las Garzas de la ciudad de San Antonio, en un principio, el comité tuvo malas experiencias con el programa, teniendo en el comité a personas que no cumplian con su responsabilidad, pero hoy ha recuperado la confianza y la solidaridad. “Prosperidad” es uno de los comites que ha logrado una buena organización y estabilidad en dicha ciudad, si bien solamente estan con el cuarto ciclo, en este tiempo han demostrado bastante capacidad de trabajar en equipo. En la fotografia tomada se encuentran 15 de las 16 integrantes del comite. Todas las integrantes tienen sus actividades propias, aunque algunas tienen trabajos formales, desarrollan sus emprendimientos en un tiempo extra para acrecentar sus ingresos. El comité lleva la mas armoniosa relacion entre todas sus miembros y han demostrado su unidad en varias ocasiones, ya sea desarrollando actividades en forma conjunta, como solucionando cualquier inconveniente siempre bajo la decisión de la mayoría.

loans.use: The credits received from Fundación Paraguaya were invested in the purchase of various items, the majority of which were supplies or merchandise for the committee members' activities.  Some of these items are: meat, beverages, rice, pasta, etc.  These articles were purchased by the women who are dedicated to sales, such as those who have grocery stores.  Those who are dedicated to other trades used their credits to purchase supplies for their activities:  thread, fabric, chemical products, etc.

loans.name: Pich

texts.en: Mrs. Pich N. is a farmer in Trapaing Tonlorp Village in Kampong Chhnang Province. Her husband, Mr. Meth Ra, is a poultry and pig breeder. Since his pigs grow bigger and bigger, Mr. Meth Ra does not have enough money to buy pig food to feed them. So his wife, Mrs. Pich N., decided to ask for a loan to buy pig food for her husband's business. Mrs. Pich N. is 28 years old and the mother of two children who are all too young to work or study.

loans.use: To buy pig food for her husband's business.

loans.name: Kelen's Mshikamano Group

texts.en:
Kelen is married with 4 children, aged between 23 and 5. She has been a clothing seller since 2000. Every day she works from 10:00 AM to 6:00 PM at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $25 from her sales.

Kelen is now requesting a loan to buy more clothes for re-sale to improve her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have businesses dealing with owning a salon and selling shoes and clothes.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for re-sale to improve her business

loans.name: Joy

texts.en:
Joy T., 34, has a retail shop selling new clothes and bags of various types on Kaaki road in Jinja. For 10 years, she has operated the shop and this is her 3rd year getting loans from Pearl Microfinance. She is married with 2 children in school and she cares for 2 step-children.

With her previous loans, Joy has been able to transform her shop in such a way that it now offers a variety of clothes and bags that was lacking before the loans. And as a result, she has been able to increase her savings and capital with her continuous involvement in small loans and this has helped her with school fees, with providing food for her family and above all with making her loan repayments on time.

Joy is now seeking a loan to be able to stock more clothes and bags in her shop. In future, she wants to expand her business by opening up another branch selling more clothes, bags, shoes and cosmetics.

loans.use: to stock more clothes and bags in her shop

loans.name: Fátima Del Rosario

texts.es:
La señora Fatima del Rosario es originaria de la ciudad de León y se dedica con ahínco al negocio de venta de chinelas para damas y caballeros ofreciendo diferentes tamaños y estilos para sus clientes en el mercado la Terminal.

Su negocio inició desde hace 8 años y hoy en día ha logrado salir adelante supliendo las necesidades de su hogar. La necesidad que ella atraviesa es la urgencia de adquirir el capital financiero para la compra de las chinelas por este motivo ha acudido a Ceprodel para obtener el crédito y así continuar con su negocio en su sector.
texts.en:
Fatima del Rosario is originally from the city of Leon and she dedicates her time with great zeal to the sale of slippers for ladies and gentlemen, offering different sizes and styles to her clients in the markets of Terminal.

Her business started 8 years ago and she has seen success, and is able to supply her household with the necessities. She sees an urgent requirement to acquire capital funds to purchase sandals. She has engaged Ceprodel to obtain this loan and continue with her business in the area.


Translated from Spanish by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase sandals.

loans.name: Karla Vanessa

texts.es: La señora Karla Vanessa Saquería Hernández tiene la edad de 35 años habita en el barrio monimbo ubicado en el cuidad de Masaya, junto a su esposo, el cual trabaja para ayudarle con los gastos del hogar, el esposo de doña Karla trabaja como técnico, ellos tienen a su cargo dos hijos los cuales estudian su primaria; los planes para su familia es mejorar la casa para brindarle mejor condición de vida, ella se desempeña como responsable de suministros del MINSA, desde hace veintiún años , doña Karla necesita el apoyo de nuestra Financiera para comprar materiales de construcción como: piedra, arena, cemento, hierro y otros para comenzar a construir su casa y tener una vivienda digna para su familia
texts.en:
Ms. Karla Vanessa Saquería Hernández is 35 years old and lives with her husband, who helps her with the household expenses, in the Monimbo neighborhood, located in the city of Masaya. Karla’s husband works as a technician. They have 2 children who attend elementary school. This family plans to make home improvements in order to have better living conditions. She has been working in MINSA (Nicaragua’s Ministry of Health) for 21 years as the person who is in charge of supplies. Karla needs our institute’s help so that she can purchase construction materials like rocks, sand, cement, steel and other supplies so that they can begin building their house and have a decent dwelling for the family.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase construction materials to build her house

loans.name: Abena

texts.en:
Abena F. is a 36 year old local restaurant operator. She is married and has five kids. Four of her children attend school while her last born has not yet started school. She prepares and sells local foods like "fufu," "banku," and other local dishes in the lorry station at Agogo, the city where she lives with her family. She has being in this business for the past five years now. "Fufu" is prepared from cooked and pounded cassava and plantain with mortar and pestle, which is taken with all kinds of soup. "Banku" is prepared from corn and cassava dough boiled and taken with hot pepper or soup.

Abena says that the prices of raw materials have gone up significantly and she needs the support of a loan to enable her meet her production costs. With the loan, she wants to purchase more raw materials, like bags of maize, baskets of cassava, plantain, meat, fish, vegetables, and firewood, to prepare her meals. She would be grateful for that assistance.

loans.use: To buy ingredients like maize, cassava, plantain, meat, fish, and vegetables.

loans.name: Hoeurn

texts.en: Mrs. Hoeurn M. is a villager in Tnaut Bak village, Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. She is a farmer who owns a piece of land to cultivate rice. She is a 59-year-old widow with two children, one of whom stays at home to do housework while the other is a construction worker. Mrs. Hoeurn M.’s first child wants to start a business by selling sugar juice ; thus, she is requesting a loan to buy glasses and other equipment for her child’s business. She hopes to increase their income and improve their living conditions with this loan.

loans.use: To start a sugar juice business.

loans.name: Helena

texts.en:
Helena A. is a fifty-two-year-old married woman with seven children. Three of her children are males and four are females. She says three of her children are in the senior high school while the rest are in the junior high and the primary school. Helena lives with her family in a house in Berekum in the Brong Ahafo region. Berekum is a busy business centre about twenty-five minutes drive from Sunyani, the regional capital. Helena’s husband owns a store in which he sells cement and other building materials.

Helena deals in all kinds of fuel – firewood, charcoal, etc., to help support her husband financially. She says she procures the firewood and the charcoal from the nearby villages and sells them in the local market square. Helena says she has been in business for six years. She wants a loan to increase her working capital so she can procure fuel in bulk. She hopes to help her husband improve their standard of living.

loans.use: To buy fuel – firewood, etc

loans.name: Akoélé

texts.fr: MmeMme Akoélé D. est née le 31 Décembre 1970 à Dalavé.
